BE11:16am

It is hard to predict how the PM will fare in the vote. On previous occasions, it has been assumed she would win with ease, but the events of recent days have left her under pressure. Around 111 Conservative MPs had indicated dissatisfaction with her Brexit deal ahead of the shelved vote, according to Buzzfeed News, but that is not to say that every one of them would want to see her replaced as leader, given the uncertainty that might bring.
Even if every one of them did vote against her, they would still need to persuade some of those who were in favour of the deal to vote with them to oust the PM, which might prove a challenge. Still, the PM might choose to resign as leader anyway, having lost the confidence of, say, a third of her party. We highlighted the possibility of a leadership contest in our reaction note on 10 December, which would play into two scenarios: (a) ‘back me or sack me’ – whereby the PM won such a vote and used that mandate to persuade MPs to pass her deal; or (b) a new leadership race, whereby she lost the vote. Indeed, as we argued in that note, in a change of leadership might not resolve the Brexit impasse ..... One of the bookies’ favourites, former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, said on 9 December on the BBC’s Andrew Marr show that he would renegotiate the deal, so that it no longer included a backstop from which the UK could not withdraw unilaterally. But this is in contrast to the assertions of chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier, who has said repeatedly that there will be no withdrawal agreement without a backstop, and that a backstop with a unilateral withdrawal option is not a backstop.

Full year guidance is cut by 25%, following poor trade. Shares have been caught up in the middle of a strategy disagreement between current management, who is turning the business from a lifestyle brand to a fast fashion wannabe, and Julian Dunkerton, larger shareholder and founder, who now wants back in to save the brand from what he believes the wrong strategy. Either way, valuation will suffer from short term volatility and the time it will take to turn around the business. Rating Hold.

BE11:29am

U-turn or acceleration of the current strategy? Is it too soon to call it a day for the current strategy implemented by the current Management (namely fast fashion this year and kidswear later on), who's asking for at least 12 months more before seeing results? We wonder how long will it take to transform a business currently characterised by 16 month lead times to a fast fashion player. One of the main points of controversy is the 35% cut to SKUs (from 6,000 to 3,900). While it makes sense on paper to reduce options to increase economies of scale, in addition to rebuilding brand equity with the equation "less is more", especially in a context of overstuffed stores, we wonder if the cut has been too deep and did not allow the business to offset sales decline driven by less options.
Valuation. The stock trades at 6.6x P/E, a 40% discount to sector 2018 Cal P/E. The challenge is to understand what is best for the brand: should shareholders stick with current management's strategy or welcome Dunkerton back? Either way, the turnaround process will inevitably take time and we remain cautious over short term performance. Rating Hold.

BE11:32am

In the near term, the stock is under pressure on challenging top-line trends (part cyclical, part structural), with an unbalanced product mix, inventory rebase overhang and inventory file consolidation (wholesale into retail/online) which creates additional execution risk in our view. Given the number of stores in the portfolio, negative retail LFLs are expected to drive operational deleverage in our view, for which the outlook remains uncertain.
Longer term, we view Superdry as an interesting growth story, with multi-channel expansion opportunities led by e-commerce. Free cash flow is healthy and shareholder returns (potential special dividends every few years) remain a rac ve, assuming top line trends can be fixed.
The public and ongoing battle for control by founders and majority shareholders Julian Dunkerton and James Holder, who are unhappy with the strategic direction of the current leadership team is not helpful, and unlikely to resolve in the near term.
The stock trades at 7.1x FY19E P/E, at a significant discount to its long run average (15x), reflecting material share price declines in recent months (-40% in the last three months).

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Given the warm weather conditions, we had expected forecast downgrades with these results and saw the level of downgrade being up to c10-15%, in keeping with the previous weather-related downgrades. Management flags an £11m trading impact on profit for November, with potential for a similar impact in December, creating a revised guidance range of £55m-£70m vs PHe £85.8m (cons £83.3m), far worse than expected. We downgrade our estimates back to c£60m, EPS 58.6p, a cut of c30%. The key question is the extent to which issues are internal vs weather related and the two are very much inter-related given Superdry’s 65% weighting to outerwear, hoodies and sweats. This point means the downgrades at Superdry are likely to far exceed potential risk in other names (downgrades to Ted were sub 10%). The interim results show 49% in underlying PBT to £12.9m vs PHe £13.5m.

BE11:33am

Cut to Hold. With the shares down greater than 30% in early trading, at c400p, Superdry is now trading on sub 7x PER, a point which reflects the lack of investor confidence given the scale of downgrades. We find ourselves in the same camp; there should be value at these levels, but we need to see more detailed trading data to gain an understanding of how the brand is performing and to what extent this is weather driven.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

In terms of mid-term guidance ..... Goldman can summarise:

BE11:39am

Group EBIT margin improvement to at least 3.5% over 5 years, £200m of cost savings, additional £200m of capex over 3 years (front loaded) but funded by reduction of working capital. Dividend rebased to 3 times earnings cover (GSe 41% payout ratio). Dixons Carphone also expects to generate more than £1bn of FCF over 5 years. As highlighted by the company, FY20 will be low point of cash flow generation due to higher capex not fully offset by working capital.

BE11:39am

What does it all mean? Other things equal, we would expect no change to consensus PBT for FY19E, nor to the Reuters consensus EBIT margin assumption for FY21 (c.3%) as we expect investments to be front loaded.

wayneJ So - some guess - SDRY has about £19.2M cash; and a working capital increase of £50M ---- and future operating lease obligations of £547M ----- so what is the chance of running it for cash and charging 'onerous lease costs'

- Whilst these four "levers" may sound a little vague to some, we are encouraged by the fact that the group is setting a number of clear financial targets, including rasing the group EBIT margin to at least 3.5% within five years (though this may not seem very ambitious given that consensus is currently expecting an EBIT margin of FY 2018/19 of 3.0%) and generating more than £1 billion of cumulative free cash flow over that period.
- We suspect, however, that for many people the headline news today will be that the group has taken the decision to rebase its dividend, reverting to its previous policy of 3x cover, which will lead to a reduction of approximately 40%. Whilst we see this as a prudent move, we think this could come as something of a surprise to the market today.

LK Hyman @BE those 4 levers of value are complete apple pie. Sell!
Irish HF guy Superdry also seems to have large unrealised forward losses, £25m at the last annual report! £300m of open fx forwards. Interesting
BE11:41am

- The company is reiterating its guidance for Headline Pre Tax Profits for the year to be around £300m. According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently looking for Dixons Carphone to deliver FY 2018/19 Pre Tax Profits of £297m (giving 20.3p of EPS), so we think it unlikely that consensus forecasts move much today.
- Based on existing consensus forecasts (which don’t reflect the dividend cut) and last night's closing price, Dixons Carphone is trading on 7.3x Cal 2019 earnings, 4.4x EBITDA with a 7.5% Dividend Yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 10.6x, 6.8x and 4.4% respectively.

BE11:57am

This is a short-term negative. Investors are likely to think along the lines of: "SBRY would be happy with the speed if it went in the right direction". We agree with this point of view and expect this to dampen the sentiment on the name in the near-term. Whilst Sainsbury's stresses this review is about process, rather than content, it still implies to us that Sainsbury's is not satisfied with the combination of both.

Do the CMA and Sainsbury's see eye-to-eye on the timeline? One could speculate probably not: the CMA has the very standard option to extend the investigation by an additional 8 weeks. This CMA investigation seems a prime candidate for an extension as it is not just about groceries but also covers: fuel, clothing, small domestic appliances, online retail. Not only is this multiple sectors, but they are also interlinked. So why did Sainsbury's feel the need today to push for an additional 11 days through a judicial process?

Merger benefits further in the future. We have been positive on the odds of the deal going through with relatively low store disposals (~80 stores). However the benefits of a good deal are nearly 2 years out in the future (closure end of this year, actual profit impact 1 year later). Good news more than 18 months out in grocery tends to carry little weight, which is why we remained neutral on SBRY. This process potentially adds further delay.

After discussion with the company, we believe the decision to seek Judicial Review is related to procedure and process, rather than specific content within material received from the CMA. However, it does appear management sees risk of the process potentially not being run as exhaustively as it could. Until more details are available we expect the market's initial reaction will be to price-in lower likelihood of the deal closing, taking into consideration that the Judicial Review may reflect management's view on the likely Phase 2 outcome.

BE11:58am

Our recent note outlined base case fair value of c.£4.00/sh, assuming the 'SASDA' merger closed with 28-54 remedy stores. Our downside case was c.£2.65/sh, if the merger failed to complete. This was based on Sainsbury's standalone EPS of £0.21/sh for FY19e and FCFE of c.£500m (also £0.21/sh). Putting these on 'through-cycle' P/E and FCF yields of c.12x and c.7.5%, respectively, gave us a valuation range of c.£2.50-2.80/sh. Sainsbury's recent 1H18/19 results showed good progress as a standalone business, we think, with grocery and Argos sales robust, retail margins stable (ex. synergy) and cashflow strong. However, we can’t discount the stock trading below standalone fair value for a period of time if perceived risk of deal failure grows.

Elliott said that several operational improvement plans have not resulted
in operational leverage. This is a valid point in our view. Despite the solid
top-line performance, operating leverage at Pernod Ricard remains
subdued as recent results show. It reported 6.5% organic EBIT growth in
fiscal 2018 on top-line growth of 5.9%. For fiscal 2019E, it guides for 5-7%
organic operating profit growth for a consensus top-line organic sales
growth estimate of c. 6%.

wayneJ “What's the point of changing the singer if you don't change the song?" - Michael Heseltine
BE12:04pm

The lack of operating leverage has held back Pernod Ricard’s EBIT margin
growth in the past. It reported an EBIT margin of 25.3% in fiscal 2010 and
27.0% in fiscal 2018. Diageo has grown its EBIT margin by more than
300bps in the same period. Its fiscal 2018 EBIT margin was 31.4%, more
than 400bps above Pernod’s. While the gap is partly explained by different regional exposures, Pernod’s margins in the individual regions are below those of Diageo, suggesting room for improvement.

12:04 pm

In the event that Pernod
Ricard acts on some of the recommendations, we expect that the benefits
will take time to filter through to growth and margins. Whether this would
really justify higher long-term valuation multiples compared to current
multiples is questionable in our view. Finally, it is good to note that the
Ricard family holds 19% of the voting rights of Pernod Ricard. We rate the
shares Hold. Our TP of EUR133 is based on a DCF model and relative
valuation multiples.
